results.statement: Vitamin D deficiency is common in patients with inflammatory bowel disease
results.reason: Multiple studies confirm high prevalence of vitamin D deficiency in IBD patients, with rates ranging from 35-70% depending on the population studied.

evidence_list.citation: Vitamin D deficiency is highly prevalent in patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), with studies showing 35-70% of IBD patients have insufficient vitamin D levels. This deficiency may contribute to disease activity and bone health complications.
Cross-sectional analysis of 965 IBD patients revealed 58% had vitamin D insufficiency (<30 ng/mL), with higher rates in Crohn's disease (62%) compared to ulcerative colitis (54%).
Vitamin D supplementation in IBD patients improved serum 25(OH)D levels but showed mixed results on disease activity outcomes in randomized controlled trials.

results.statement: All cases of childhood ulcerative colitis require colectomy
results.reason: Evidence clearly shows that colectomy is NOT required for all cases. While some severe or refractory cases may need surgery, many children achieve remission with medical therapy.

evidence_list.citation: Pediatric ulcerative colitis management has evolved with biologic therapies, allowing many children to avoid colectomy. Current data shows approximately 10-20% of pediatric UC patients require colectomy within 5 years of diagnosis.

A multicenter study of 340 children with UC found that 82% achieved clinical remission with medical therapy (5-ASA, immunomodulators, or biologics) and did not require surgical intervention during 3-year follow-up.
Indications for colectomy in pediatric UC include medically refractory disease, toxic megacolon, perforation, dysplasia, or cancer. These severe complications affect a minority of patients.

results.statement: Probiotics are effective for all forms of inflammatory bowel disease
results.reason: Evidence is mixed. Some probiotic strains show benefit for specific conditions (e.g., VSL#3 for pouchitis), but efficacy varies by IBD type, strain used, and individual patient factors. Not effective for all forms.

evidence_list.citation: VSL#3 probiotic mixture demonstrated efficacy in maintaining remission of chronic pouchitis in randomized controlled trials, with 85% of patients maintaining remission vs. 6% with placebo.
Meta-analysis of probiotic trials in Crohn's disease showed no significant benefit for inducing or maintaining remission, with most studies showing neutral or negative results.

Probiotic efficacy in ulcerative colitis appears strain-specific and modest. E. coli Nissle 1917 showed equivalence to mesalamine for maintaining remission in some trials, but other strains showed minimal benefit.
Current clinical guidelines recommend probiotics only for specific indications (pouchitis prevention/treatment) and note insufficient evidence to recommend routine use across all IBD subtypes.
